Yes, I think we do (though I've been wrong before). The gz tool works even when gzserver is not running, it has the following output:


```
#!js

$ gz topic -l
An instance of Gazebo is not running.
```

If we add it to the gazebo prototype, we'll only be allowed to call it if we create an instance of gzserver. Then it would be possible to get topics from a different instance of gzserver, depending on what the GAZEBO_MASTER_URI is set to.

So this is not about how to do things better, but how to expose the same functionality. If you want to implement a replacement for `gz` tools in javascript, its better not to impose things like starting a new server to see if messages exits.
